docs.lead_paragraph: THIS is the year that demographers have been warning about, when baby boomers start turning 60. For years, the arrival of the country's biggest demographic group, roughly 76 million people born between 1946 and 1964, to the retirement ranks has prompted debates over health care, Social Security benefits, housing and entertainment -- the full spectrum of American life.

headline.main: 76 Million Reasons to Reconsider What Is Typical for Those Over 60

docs.abstract: Americans in nation's biggest demographic group, some 76 million baby boomers, start turning 60 this year, entering retirement ranks and prompting debates about health care, Social Security, housing and entertainment; population and retirement patterns discussed; demographic and social charts (special section, Retirement)
docs.snippet: A few retirement trends based on government statistics  and informed speculation on how they could play out in the future  have begun to emerge.

byline.original: By TERRY SCHWADRON; Janet Roberts contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE'S a checklist for people in their mid-50's who are thinking about the new retirement, the one that starts before 65 and means still working, but in a more appealing job, for shorter hours or for yourself: kids through college? Check. Marketable skills? Check. Enough in the bank to make up for a step-down in pay? Check. Now add one more item: a total of $50,000 to $100,000, or in some cases more, to cover health insurance until you qualify for Medicare -- assuming you are healthy enough to qualify for insurance at all.

headline.main: Want to Retire Early and Hang a Shingle? It'll Cost You

docs.abstract: Economists warn that evaporation of health benefits for younger retirees will play important role in final career trajectory of baby boom generation, perhaps determining whether next decade sees outpouring of new ventures or office cubicles clogged with workers waiting for Medicare; graph showing decline percentage of private-sector employers offering health insurance to retirees (special section, Retirement)
docs.snippet: The evaporation of health benefits for younger retirees will play an important role in the final career trajectory of the baby boom generation, economists say.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was a sunny midafternoon in a shiny new global-economy mall in San Salvador, the capital city of El Salvador, and a young woman I was hoping to meet appeared to be getting cold feet. She had agreed to rendezvous with a go-between not far from the Payless shoe store and then come to a nearby hotel to talk to me. She was an hour late. Alone in the hotel lobby, I was feeling nervous; I was stood up the day before by another woman in a similar situation. I had been warned that interviewing anyone who had had an abortion in El Salvador would be difficult. The problem was not simply that in this very Catholic country a shy 24-year-old unmarried woman might feel shame telling her story to an older man. There was also the criminal stigma. And this was why I had come to El Salvador: Abortion is a serious felony here for everyone involved, including the woman who has the abortion. Some young women are now serving prison sentences, a few as long as 30 years.
docs.abstract: Jack Hitt article on El Salvador as illustration of what happens when abortion is criminalized; notes that El Salvador amended its constitution in late 1990's to ban abortion under all circumstances--even to save life of mother--and has in place active law-enforcement apparatus committed to capturing, trying and incarcerating everyone involved in abortion, including woman who has one; says mandate toward saving fetus at all cost is so strong that doctors cannot operate on woman with ectopic pregnancy until fetus dies or fallopian tube is ruptured; photos (L)
docs.snippet: What happens when you completely criminalize abortion? Over the last eight years, El Salvador has found out.
